title: Matrix Modeling - predicting a steady state

content.question:
The diagram shows two states, labeled 1 and 2.

A loop from state 1 pointing back to state 1 is labeled 0.5.

An arrow from state 1 to state 2 is labeled 0.5.

A loop from state 2 pointing back to state 2 is labeled 0.5.

An arrow from state 2 to state 1 is labeled 0.5.

Objects in a system can be in two possible states: state <math alttext="1"><mn>1</mn></math> and state <math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math>. The state transition diagram for this situation is given. Which of the following is true?

choices.label: <math alttext="50 percent sign"><mn>50</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of objects are remaining and leaving both state <math alttext="1"><mn>1</mn></math> and state <math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math>. Therefore, this system cannot approach a steady state.

<math alttext="50 percent sign"><mn>50</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of objects are remaining and leaving both state <math alttext="1"><mn>1</mn></math> and state <math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math>. Therefore, if the initial percent of objects in state <math alttext="1"><mn>1</mn></math> is <math alttext="x percent sign"><mi>x</mi><mo>%</mo></math>, and the initial percent of objects in state <math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math> is <math alttext="y percent sign"><mi>y</mi><mo>%</mo></math>, then the steady state of state <math alttext="1"><mn>1</mn></math> is <math alttext="x percent sign"><mi>x</mi><mo>%</mo></math>, and the steady state of state <math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math> is <math alttext="y percent sign"><mi>y</mi><mo>%</mo></math>. The percentages will never change from state <math alttext="1"><mn>1</mn></math> being <math alttext="x percent sign"><mi>x</mi><mo>%</mo></math> and state <math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math> being <math alttext="y percent sign"><mi>y</mi><mo>%</mo></math>.

Therefore, if the initial percent of objects in state <math alttext="1"><mn>1</mn></math> is <math alttext="x percent sign"><mi>x</mi><mo>%</mo></math>, and the initial percent of objects in state <math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math> is <math alttext="y percent sign"><mi>y</mi><mo>%</mo></math>, then the steady state of state <math alttext="1"><mn>1</mn></math> is <math alttext="x percent sign"><mi>x</mi><mo>%</mo></math>, and the steady state of state <math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math> is <math alttext="y percent sign"><mi>y</mi><mo>%</mo></math>—even though the percentages may change on the way to a steady state.

Therefore, no matter the initial percent of objects in state <math alttext="1"><mn>1</mn></math> and the initial percent of objects in state <math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math>, the steady state of state <math alttext="1"><mn>1</mn></math> is <math alttext="50 percent sign"><mn>50</mn><mo>%</mo></math> and the steady state of state <math alttext="2"><mn>2</mn></math> is <math alttext="50 percent sign"><mn>50</mn><mo>%</mo></math>.
